There are more than 25 trillion red cells in the approximately 5.3 quarts of blood found in an average 170-pound man. But the spleen and other organs usually destroy about 200 billion of these cells each day, giving red blood cells in the circulatory system a life span of only about four months. Red blood cells must there fore be produced at a rapid rate, inside the bone marrow.
Blood not only provides food, oxygen, waste disposal and protection from infection, it also closes minor wounds. It does this through the process of clotting, which prevents the body from continuing to lose blood and prevents sources of infection from entering the body. Clotting begins when platelets start to break up around the wound, triggering a series of chemical changes which produce a clotting enzyme. Once the body has begun to heal itself, however, proteins in the plasma dissolve the clots, keeping the blood vessels un obstructed and in good working condition.
